TITLE: These states are raising their minimum wages in 2023. Chart shows where workers can expect higher pay
SUMMARY: As the calendar turns to a new year, as many as 26 states are expected to mandate a higher minimum wage.

TITLE: There's still time to get health insurance through the public exchange — and you may qualify for help paying premiums
SUMMARY: If you don't have a health plan, you can sign up for one through the federal marketplace until Jan. 15.

TITLE: The Mega Millions jackpot is $785 million. Taking the lump sum is 'typically a big mistake,' lottery lawyer says
SUMMARY: Nearly all winners opt for the lump sum, but with $785 million at stake, there are significant advantages to spreading out this lottery windfall.

TITLE: Secure 2.0 changes 3 key rules around required withdrawals from retirement accounts
SUMMARY: President Joe Biden signed a $1.7 trillion legislative package Thursday with updates to required minimum distribution rules for retirement accounts.

TITLE: Mega Millions jackpot surges to $785 million. If there's a winner, this is the tax bill
SUMMARY: If the winner were to take the lump-sum cash option of $403.8 million, the federal tax withholding would be $96.9 million — and more likely would be owed.

TITLE: It's time to boost 401(k) contributions for 2023: 'You're smart to jump on this,' says advisor
SUMMARY: You can defer $22,500 into your 401(k) for 2023, up from $20,500 in 2022. Here's why it's time to boost your contributions, according to financial experts.

TITLE: Don't assume the interest on your savings account is keeping up with Federal Reserve rate hikes. Here's why
SUMMARY: You may assume the Federal Reserve rate hikes mean you are making higher interest on your cash. Here's why you could be wrong.

TITLE: Share of new car buyers with a monthly payment of more than $1,000 hits record high
SUMMARY: High prices and rising interest rates are causing an affordability problem for many car shoppers.

TITLE: Workers still quitting at high rates — and getting a big bump in pay
SUMMARY: The so-called quits rate has fallen from a pandemic-era peak but is still at a historical high. Workers stand to reap a big financial benefit — in higher pay.

TITLE: Paid biweekly? Here are your 2 three-paycheck months in 2023 — and how to plan for them
SUMMARY: If you get paid biweekly as a W-2 employee, there are usually two months out of the year when you will receive three paychecks instead of two.

TITLE: Here are some strategies that can help you dig out of holiday debt
SUMMARY: Americans spent more this holiday season and will likely take their time paying off any debt incurred. Here are seven steps that can help tackle debt.

TITLE: Where to keep your cash amid high inflation and rising interest rates: It's 'a little tricky,' says expert
SUMMARY: There are many options when saving for short-term goals, and it's trickier amid high inflation and rising interest rates. Here's what savers need to know.

TITLE: IRS: Taxpayers may avoid a surprise tax bill by making a quarterly payment by Jan. 17
SUMMARY: The fourth-quarter estimated tax deadline is Jan. 17. Here's how to avoid a 'surprise tax bill' for 2022, according to the IRS.

TITLE: Here's what people with long Covid need to know about navigating health insurance
SUMMARY: Patients with long Covid may experience disruptions to their health insurance coverage if they lose their job. Fortunately, they have other options to turn to.

TITLE: Credit card interest rates are heading to 20% on average — here’s the best way to pay down high-interest debt
SUMMARY: As the Federal Reserve remains committed to raising interest rates to combat inflation, credit card rates will hit fresh highs in the year ahead.

TITLE: Falling behind on student loans can reduce Social Security benefits by $2,500 a year
SUMMARY: If you are delinquent on federal student loans and collect Social Security benefits, your monthly checks could be reduced.

TITLE: Biden administration files its brief with the Supreme Court, defending student loan forgiveness
SUMMARY: The Biden administration filed a legal brief with the U.S. Supreme Court, defending its plan to cancel hundreds of billions of dollars in student debt.

TITLE: Homeowners spent up to $6,000 on average on repairs and maintenance in 2022. Here's how to keep those costs down
SUMMARY: While some home-related expenses are tricky to predict, there are things you can do to lessen their sting, according to experts.

TITLE: You may get extra time to spend unused 2022 funds in your flex spending account. What to know about the rules
SUMMARY: About three-quarters of employers either give their workers a grace period to spend 2022 FSA funds or let them carry over a limited amount.

TITLE: Think you've got investing skill? Your overconfidence may be costly
SUMMARY: A new report suggests many investors, especially younger ones, are overconfident in their abilities. That behavioral bias may lead to loss or too much risk.

TITLE: How to balance retirement and emergency savings in a shaky economy
SUMMARY: Experts cover how to decide between saving to your 401(k) for retirement versus your emergency fund in an unsteady economy.

TITLE: Mega Millions jackpot is $940 million: Here's what to do if you come into a large sum of money
SUMMARY: Whether it's an inheritance, sale of a property, bonus or even a tax refund, there are many ways to end up with a windfall apart from winning the lottery.

TITLE: Here are key things you need to know if you’re eyeing a Medigap policy alongside basic Medicare
SUMMARY: For some Medicare beneficiaries, a Medigap plan ends up being the best fit for supplemental coverage. Here's what to consider when choosing one.

TITLE: After job cuts, here's how leaders can boost 'layoff survivor' morale and productivity
SUMMARY: After a layoff, companies are often left with employees who are less trusting, less committed and less satisfied. Here's how leaders can mitigate the damage.

TITLE: Trump's tax returns show no Social Security benefit income. Here's what retirees can learn about claiming
SUMMARY: The former commander in chief seems to have foregone Social Security benefit income. But you may not want to employ that strategy yourself.

TITLE: Here are key things you need to know if you're eyeing a Medigap policy alongside basic Medicare
SUMMARY: For some Medicare beneficiaries, a Medigap plan ends up being the best fit for supplemental coverage. Here's what to consider when choosing one.
